title: Will the United Arab Emirates (UAE) be ranked higher than 21st in the Global Food Security Index Rankings for 2020?
preds:
Visibly the government is communicating and implementing ever stricter food safety measures in 2020. (source: https://www.iofs.org.kz/fr/post/155)
This should have a positive or neutral influence on the ranking. On the other hand the trend between 2018 and 2019 of the country was already improving in the ranking. And one country in the top 21 (United Kingdom), on the other hand, had a trend towards less food security. (source: https://foodsecurityindex.eiu.com/Index)

The Coronavirus Pandemic doesn't seem to have a big effect on most of the underlying factors of the food security index. Also because the availability was just slightly effected (http://www.fao.org/documents/card/en/c/cb1993en)  It could only have a bigger effect on the affordability because of the economic downturn. But the UAE seems to be less severe effected by the economic consequences than the countries close to it on the FSI.

Historically, UAE has entered the rankings in the top 30 has bounced around the 20s and low 30s. There is evidence that UAE is investing resources, adopting domestic and foreign policy to support this industry. UAE made an impressive jump from 31 to 21 in 2019 and seems to on a tear related to foodstuffs exports. The bouncing around in the ranking makes it difficult to forecast. For comparison here is the number ranked county, Singapore, who is also a small export oriented county: 2019 1st- Singapore
Food Stuffs Export $10.3 Billion Growth 43.9%
Food Stuffs Import $6.74 Billion Growth 6.53% 2019 21st- UAE
Food Stuffs Export $7.43 Billion Growth 275%
Food Stuffs Import $6.26 Billion  Growth 4.11%
https://oec.world/en/profile/hs92/foodstuffs#trade Policy and Investment anedotes from articles:
"Now, [the UAE] has risen to 21st. “Our main goal is to become number one by 2051,” says Ms Al Mheiri.
To do that the UAE is turning to technology. There have been huge investments in the AgTech sector, with the Abu Dhabi government revealing a 1 billion dirham incentive package in 2019.
Just last month Abu Dhabi’s RainMakers Capital Investment and GrowGroup IFS from the Netherlands revealed plans for the world’s largest indoor farm – a 17.5 hectare plot with the ability to produce 10,000 tonnes of fresh produce every year.
“The UAE imports 90% of its food, which is not a bad thing,” she explains. “We still want to be a hub for food trade, we still want food to flow to the UAE, we want to increase imports, we want to increase exports and re-exports, but we want to be less dependent on net imports into the country."
https://www.caterermiddleeast.com/suppliers/85283-how-chefs-and-suppliers-can-help-the-uae-become-a-world-leader-in-food-security The UAE currently ranks 21 in the Global Food Security Index, but it aims to be within the top ten by 2021. It was ranked 31 in 2018, so it is possible that it could achieve that goal if it continues to develop domestic food production systems and diversify the sources of imported food. According to Ms Al Muhairi, ‘we need to diversify, with some food grown at home, some food grown by our companies abroad and some imported from different sources.’ The UAE has agricultural investments in a range of countries, including Romania, Egypt, Sudan, Serbia, Cambodia, Uganda and Australia.
Israel is one of the global leaders in dry-land agriculture and water conservation. Since the country was established in 1948, it has been a global leader in the development of desalination, drip irrigation, wastewater recycling and water supply and demand management.
New opportunities for closer Israeli and Emirati collaboration on food and water security initiatives is likely to be one of the outcomes of the normalisation of diplomatic relations between the two countries.
https://www.futuredirections.org.au/publication/uae-and-israel-discuss-closer-co-operation-in-food-and-water-security/ Historic Rankings
2019- 21
2018- 31
2017- 33
2016- 30
2015- 23
2014- 30 (first time UAE was ranked)

The Food and Agricultural Organization of the United Nations defines food security as having sufficient quality food by either domestic supply or imports and adequate access to and resources for nutritious  food requirements.
The major issue is that due to its harsh climate and lack of water resources the UAE must import 85-90% of its food requirements. Global climate changes can only exacerbate these issues.
As stated, the Gulf countries are dependent on the openness of the world markets and any problems in the producing countries will result in problems for the end user i.e. the UAE.
Therefore, to some degree food security is beyond control of the authorities in the UAE. They have the financial resources to acquire the required produce, but a bad harvest, politics or Force Majeure may pause or prevent delivery.
Covid-19 would have an adverse effect of food delivery, given the pandemic may affect the production of food in the producing countries.
The UAE’s position on the Global Food Security Index can only rise to a certain point given the lack of control. https://www.thenational.ae/lifestyle/food/food-security-a-growing-concern-for-the-uae-1.562078
https://www.mocaf.gov.ae/en/media/news/uae-s-global-food-security-index-improvements-discussed  https://foodsecurityindex.eiu.com/Index  https://foodtechchallenge.com  https://www.pharmaceutical-technology.com/fdi/the-gcc-emerges-as-a-food-security-force/  https://apps.fas.usda.gov/newgainapi/api/Report/DownloadReportByFileName?fileName=UAE%20Food%20Security%20Council_Dubai_United%20Arab%20Emirates_02-29-2020
Currently tied with Japan, last year UAE grew faster than Japan so a trend continuation would see it overtake Japan
With COVID all processes for increasing health and food safety are constantly monitored, revised and improved.

Thanks to @sebawi for the analysis. [1] I'd add that the UAE improved their score from 2018 by +1 whereas close competitors Italy and Japan improved by +0.6 and +0.3, respectively. [2] Other competitors also improved by less - Portugal (+0.1), Poland (+0.7), Chile (+0.9), and Spain (+0.6). I'm only worried about Kuwait - while they ranked further behind at 27th with a score of 74.8, they gained +3.2 points from 2018. With another improvement like that they would overtake the UAE, which scored 76.5. I looked at the 2018 report to try to get a better historical picture but the numbers didn't add up - maybe I'm reading it incorrectly. I think the UAE's focus on food security will let them prevail but I'm not as certain as the crowd. [1] https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1043756
[2] 2019 report can be downloaded at: https://foodsecurityindex.eiu.com/Resources
It would be ridiculous if they didn't make it give all resources they are throwing at it https://www.khaleejtimes.com/news/general/uae-launches-system-to-increase-food-security-

COVID-19 has increased food insecurity globally. Japan (like many other countries) has felt these effects. They've seen a decline in food distribution in some areas, but stability and increases in others. They've also relaxed strict food labeling policies, but they're touting food safety. Moreover,  last year, Japan's food sufficiency rate reached an all-time low. Comparatively,  United Arab Emirates (UAE) are actively implementing measures to ensure food sufficiency. The Abu Dhabi Agriculture and Food Safety Authority (ADAFSA) also just released new food safety guidelines. Finally, the Emirates Food Security Council seems determined to move UAE to the top 10 in the Global Food Security Index rankings by 2021 and to number 1 position by 2051. The UAE appear to be working on improving food security in their country, while Japan seems content and not as determined to improve food security. So, as long as they stay dedicated to ensuring food sufficiency and security, the UAE should have a fairly easy time overtaking Japan (and liking others) in the rankings.

They seem pretty confident, see  1)https://www.zawya.com/mena/en/press-releases/story/Upcoming_Global_Trends_and_the_UAEs_Global_Food_Security_Index_improvements_discussed_with_the_food_policy_benchmarking_tools_architects-ZAWYA20200617132857/ and
2) http://tradearabia.com/news/MISC_369241.html

Reasons
1. UAE was already lied for 21st position in 2019.
2. Any country that has the gazillion (not an accurate count) dollars to throw at a problem can get its global rankings up on most anything, if they so desire.
3. Getting its ranking up by 1 is hardly a stretch, and with enough high paid expats expert consultants to move the needle, heads would roll if it didn't.

In order to move to 21, UAE will have to advance against in ranking against very secure nations. UAE can improve food security only to a point using advanced technology, whereas nations like Portugal and New Zealand possess natural ag advantage.
The UAE appears to have the ambition to acheive this aim and I beleive they have the resources to make it happen.

Supply will decline. Food costs will increase. Food safety will decrease. Imports and exports will both decline. Food supply chain disruptions will be rampant. Political stability will decline systematically as food supply is threatened. See USA for reference.

Saudi has a record of bad policy decisions in food production. Increased urban population. Over investment in food production overseas, in areas already underperforming in food production, which creates insecure supply.  Finite aquifers at home. Less money in the kitty than supposed, due to crash in oil prices. High unemployment - those petroleum plants become more automated. And, countries currently below 21 on the 2019 index will climb, pushing Saudi further down.

This question is asked, UAE trying to optimize for the index - in particular more R&D, Covid hitting Portugal and other countries way harder. See https://gulfnews.com/business/how-the-uae-reaps-the-harvest-of-food-security-in-the-aftermath-of-covid-19-1.1590651011647 Considerations for No: Distance to Portugal is 1.2 which is pretty large and nations ranked higher >2. Pretty large gap to close despite covid throwing things around.

Hattip to @RRG for the overview [1]! From my point of view, there are two mechanisms at work determining the position of a country in the index. 1) The performance of the country of interest
2) The performance of competing countries Both of them are driven by the performance in the sub-indices that are used to calculate the overall index. So let's take a look at them and what they are ought to measure [8]. I. Affordability, includes:
- change in average food costs
- proportion of population under global poverty line
- GDP per capita
- agricultural import tariffs
- presence of food safety-net programmes (presence, funding, coverage, operation)
- access to financing for farmers II. Availability
- sufficiency of supply
- public expenditure on agricultural R&D
- agricultural infrastructure
- volatility of agricultural production
- political stability risk
- corruption
- urban absorption capacity
- food loss III. Quality & Safety
- dietary diversity
- nutritional standards (dietary guidelines, national plan/strategy, monitoring and surveillance)
- micronutrient availability (vitamin A, iron, zinc)
- protein quality
- food safety (food surveillance agency, access to potable water, ability to store food safely) IV. Natural Resources & Resilience
- exposure (environmental factors such as temperature rise, drought; commitment to managing exposure)
- water (agricultural water risk)
- land (degradation, grassland, forest change)
- oceans (eutrophication, biodiversity, marine protected areas)
- sensitivity (import dependency, dependence on natural capital, disaster risk management)
- adaptive capacity (early warning measures, national agricultural risk management system)
- demographic stress (population growth, urbanisation) The UAE performs well regarding affordability (4th rank), comparably well on availability (39th rank) and on Quality & Safety (26th rank), and abysmal on Natural Resources & Resilience (106th ranks). Potential for improvement is certainly in those areas that are able to adjust in the short term.  Judging from the media coverage [2,3,4,5], the UAE may focus on some parts that would fall into this category such as food surveillance [2]. It also seems like that they are actively working on achieving goals that contribute to their position in the Food Security Index [3]. More information on the Food Security Council [6,7]. In the next forecast, I'll take a closer look at the direct competitors: Japan and Italy. [1] https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/1039100
[2] http://www.tradearabia.com/news/MISC_368161.html
[3] https://gulfnews.com/uae/government/five-ministries-part-of-uaes-new-food-security-council-1.68979150
[4] https://gulfnews.com/business/how-the-uae-reaps-the-harvest-of-food-security-in-the-aftermath-of-covid-19-1.1590651011647
[5] https://www.gulftoday.ae/opinion/2020/05/07/uae-efforts-to-build-resilient-food-system-fruitful
[6] https://foodsecurity.gov.ae/
[7] https://u.ae/en/information-and-services/environment-and-energy/food-security
[8] Download report here: https://foodsecurityindex.eiu.com/Resources

Some years ago there was a big food scandal in UAE and the Emirates Food Security Agency reacted very strictly with closing of factories and shop and markets. They understood that there is a need for getting trust of the UAE people and the tourists or importing countries where the UAE is exporting to.
Because the rest of the world is in worse shape this year and because the UAE will have lost a significant number of the poorest members of its society-- foreigners who returned home.

In 2019, UAE shared the 21st position with Japan with scores not insignificantly for availability, safety and quality. In order to enhance the above-mentioned parameters, UAE must address the challenges mentioned in a policy paper. UAE has recognized food security as a strategic priority by creating a new ministry for food security. 
Some of the key areas of intervention that will push the position up are investments in R&D for food production sector, increased collaboration in the agricultural sector at the international level in Universities, research institutions, etc.

The 2019 report is available in its entirety here - https://foodsecurityindex.eiu.com/Resources.   The UAE ranked 21st, the whole list from 1st to 35th being (sorry for the bad formatting - did not want to add to the length) Rank Country Score /100
1 Singapore 87.4, 2 Ireland 84.0, 3 United States 83.7, 4 Switzerland 83.1, =5 Finland 82.9, =5 Norway 82.9, 7 Sweden 82.7, 8 Canada 82.4, 9 Netherlands 82.0, 10 Austria 81.7, 11 Germany 81.5, 12 Australia 81.4, 13 Qatar 81.2, 14 Denmark 81.0, 15 Belgium 80.7, 16 France 80.4, 17 United Kingdom 79.1, 18 Israel 79.0, 19 New Zealand 78.8, 20 Portugal 77.8, =21 Japan 76.5, =21 United Arab Emirates 76.5, 23 Italy 75.8, 24 Poland 75.6, =25 Chile 75.5, =25 Spain 75.5, 27 Kuwait 74.8, 28 Malaysia 73.8, 29 South Korea 73.6, 30 Saudi Arabia 73.5, 31 Greece 73.4, 32 Czech Republic 73.1, 33 Uruguay 72.8, 34 Hungary 72.7, 35 China 71.0 The 4 major factors contributing to the Index are (please see the detailed report for how these factors are calculated)
1. Affordability                                                                        (UAE current ranking - 4)
2. Availability                                                                           (UAE current ranking - 39)
3. Quality & Safety                                                                  (UAE current ranking - 26)
4. Natural Resources & Resilience                                       (UAE current ranking - 106) So, UAE is pretty much hampered by the NR&R (which cant really be improved in the short term), and makes up with Affordability, Availability and Q&S.  I would give a baseline of 50% and wait and watch.

Knee-jerk prediction, will investigate further:
Rationale being... deep pockets and a desire for notoriety/optics.
